title: Your body's real age

multiple-choice.question: What is the approximate lifespan of a hair on a human head?
Which part of the body is completely renewed approximately every six months?
How often are the cells in the lining of the stomach and intestines typically replaced?
What is the approximate time it takes for the outer layer of skin to be completely renewed?
What is the estimated lifespan of a red blood cell in the human body?
What is the approximate time it takes for most of the fat cells in the human body to turn over?
Which part of the human body remains relatively unchanged throughout life?
According to the transcript, what is the approximate time it takes for the skeleton to be completely renewed?
What is unique about the cells that make up the brain compared to other parts of the body?

options.label: C
options.text: The brain cells are constantly being replaced

options.label: D
options.text: The brain cells are relatively static, with most neurons developed before birth

multiple-choice.question: What is the main function of the lens of the eye mentioned in the transcript?

options.label: D
options.text: To serve as the window through which we see

title: What you don't know about who you will become

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is one reason why people often regret the decisions they made in the past?

options.label: A
options.text: They were influenced by external factors.

options.label: B
options.text: They had a fundamental misconception about the power of time.

options.label: C
options.text: They didn't consider the long-term consequences of their choices.

options.label: D
options.text: They were too young to make informed decisions.

multiple-choice.question: What is the "end of history" illusion, as described by the speaker?

options.label: A
options.text: The idea that people's values and personalities remain constant over time.

options.label: B
options.text: The idea that people's values and personalities change rapidly over time.

options.label: C
options.text: The idea that people overestimate how much they will change in the future.

options.label: D
options.text: The idea that people underestimate how much they will change in the future.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker's study, what do people tend to do when predicting how much their values will change in the next 10 years?

options.label: A
options.text: They overestimate the amount of change.

options.label: B
options.text: They underestimate the amount of change.

options.label: C
options.text: They accurately predict the amount of change.

options.label: D
options.text: They are unable to predict the amount of change.

multiple-choice.question: What is one consequence of the "end of history" illusion, according to the speaker?

options.label: A
options.text: People make more informed decisions about their future.

options.label: B
options.text: People are more open to new experiences.

options.label: C
options.text: People overpay for opportunities to indulge their current preferences.

options.label: D
options.text: People are more likely to take risks.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, why do people tend to overpay for opportunities to indulge their current preferences?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they are trying to hold onto their current values and personality.

options.label: B
options.text: Because they are trying to relive past experiences.

options.label: C
options.text: Because they overestimate the stability of their current preferences.

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are trying to impress others.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is one reason why people tend to underestimate the amount of change they will experience in the future?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they are afraid of change.

options.label: B
options.text: Because they are too focused on the present.

options.label: C
options.text: Because they find it hard to imagine who they will be in the future.

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are too confident in their predictions.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, how do people's perceptions of change in their personal values and personalities change as they age?

options.label: A
options.text: People believe that change slows down as they age, and this perception is accurate.

options.label: B
options.text: People believe that change slows down as they age, but this perception is inaccurate.

options.label: C
options.text: People believe that change speeds up as they age, and this perception is accurate.

options.label: D
options.text: People believe that change speeds up as they age, but this perception is inaccurate.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the relationship between people's age and their perception of personal change?

options.label: A
options.text: People accurately perceive that change slows down as they age.

options.label: B
options.text: People believe that change slows down as they age, but it actually slows down less than they think.

options.label: C
options.text: People believe that change speeds up as they age, and this perception is accurate.

options.label: D
options.text: People believe that change speeds up as they age, but it actually slows down.

multiple-choice.question: What does the speaker mean by saying that "human beings are works in progress that mistakenly think they're finished"?

options.label: A
options.text: People are constantly changing, but they don't realize it.

options.label: B
options.text: People are static and unchanging, but they think they are evolving.

options.label: C
options.text: People are aware of their personal growth, but they don't acknowledge it.

options.label: D
options.text: People are unaware of their personal growth, and they don't care about it.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the result of comparing people's predictions of change in their values over the next 10 years with the reports of people who are 10 years older?

options.label: A
options.text: People accurately predict the amount of change they will experience.

options.label: B
options.text: People overestimate the amount of change they will experience.

options.label: C
options.text: People underestimate the amount of change they will experience.

options.label: D
options.text: People are unable to predict the amount of change they will experience.

title: How smart are orangutans? - Lu Gao

options.text: To teach them how to use tools

options.label: C

options.label: C

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: C
options.text: By recovering from emotional trauma and continuing to develop essential life skills

title: Why can't we just print money to pay off debt?

options.label: B
options.text: Decreased prices and higher savings rates

title: Does this look white to you?

multiple-choice.question: Why does your brain perceive a blue dot moving around a circle when it's not actually there?

options.label: A
options.text: The blue dot is reflecting light in a way that creates an optical illusion.

options.label: B
options.text: Your brain is being tricked by the way your eyes process visual information.

options.label: C
options.text: The circle is spinning too fast for you to see the dot.

options.label: D
options.text: The dot is actually moving, but you're not seeing it.

multiple-choice.question: What color do you perceive when you mix red and green light together?
What are the light-sensitive cells in your retina that perceive color and work together to allow you to see a range of colors?
Why do you perceive yellow when you mix red and green light together?

options.label: A
options.text: Because yellow is a primary color.

options.label: B
options.text: Because your brain combines the responses from the red and green cones.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the light is reflecting off a yellow surface.

options.label: D
options.text: Because there is actually yellow light present.

multiple-choice.question: What happens to your blue cone when you stare at a yellow light for a while and then suddenly switch to a white screen?

options.label: A
options.text: It becomes excited and sends a stronger signal to your brain.

options.label: B
options.text: It becomes dulled and sends a weaker signal to your brain.

options.label: C
options.text: It stays the same and sends the same signal to your brain.

options.label: D
options.text: It is not affected and does not send a signal to your brain.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between complementary colors on a paint color wheel and complementary colors for light?

options.label: A
options.text: Complementary colors on a paint color wheel produce a darker color when mixed, while complementary colors for light produce a shade of gray.

options.label: B
options.text: Complementary colors on a paint color wheel are opposite each other, while complementary colors for light are the same.

options.label: C
options.text: Complementary colors on a paint color wheel absorb more light, while complementary colors for light reflect more light.

options.label: D
options.text: Complementary colors on a paint color wheel produce a darker color when mixed, while complementary colors for light produce white when mixed.

multiple-choice.question: What phenomenon occurs when you mix two complementary colors of light together?

options.label: A
options.text: Additive color mixing, resulting in a darker color.

options.label: B
options.text: Subtractive color mixing, resulting in a shade of gray.

options.label: C
options.text: Complementary color mixing, resulting in a range of colors.

options.label: D
options.text: Additive color mixing, resulting in white light.

multiple-choice.question: Why do you perceive a mix of colors when you mix different wavelengths of light together?

options.label: A
options.text: Because your brain is being tricked by the way your eyes process visual information.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the light is reflecting off a surface that has multiple colors.

options.label: C
options.text: Because there is actually a mix of colors present.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the light is being absorbed by a surface that has multiple colors.

multiple-choice.question: What happens when you shine red, green, and blue light on your eyes?

options.label: A
options.text: You see a mix of red and green light.

options.label: B
options.text: You see a mix of blue and yellow light.

options.label: C
options.text: You see white light because all three cones are excited.

options.label: D
options.text: You see no light at all because the cones are not excited.

multiple-choice.question: Which type of cone is sensitive to blue light and plays a crucial role in perceiving colors?

title: Are spotty fruits and vegetables safe to eat? - Elizabeth Brauer

multiple-choice.question: What percentage of fruits and vegetables were wasted by American retailers and shoppers in 2010 due to cosmetic problems and perceived spoilage?

options.label: B
options.text: Human immune systems are similar to plant immune systems

options.label: C
options.text: Human immune systems have developed specific defenses against plant pathogens

options.text: Human immune systems are different enough from plant immune systems

options.label: C

title: This Video Will Make You Angry

multiple-choice.question: What happens to a thought when it is not being thought by a brain?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: It dies and ceases to exist

options.label: C
options.text: It spreads rapidly to other brains

options.label: D
options.text: It changes form and becomes a different thought

options.label: A
options.text: Thoughts are like plants that grow and evolve

options.label: B
options.text: Thoughts are like animals that compete and cooperate

options.label: C
options.text: Thoughts are like germs that spread and infect

options.label: D
options.text: Thoughts are like machines that process and transmit information

options.label: A
options.text: They die quickly and are forgotten

options.label: C
options.text: They change form and become different thoughts

options.label: D
options.text: They become weaker and less influential

options.label: B
options.text: The Internet has no effect on thought germs and their spread

options.label: C
options.text: The Internet helps thought germs spread rapidly and evolve effectively

options.label: D
options.text: The Internet only affects certain types of thought germs

multiple-choice.question: What happens to thought germs that undergo random changes as they spread, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: They become weaker and less influential

options.label: B
options.text: They become stronger and more effective

options.label: C
options.text: They remain the same and do not change

options.label: D
options.text: They die quickly and are forgotten

multiple-choice.question: What term is used in the transcript to describe the relationship between two opposing thought germs that work together to spread and hold their thoughts?

options.label: A
options.text: They eventually come to an agreement and resolve their differences

options.label: B
options.text: They become more divided and entrenched in their positions, often arguing with themselves about the opposing group

options.label: C
options.text: They stop arguing and lose interest in the topic

options.label: D
options.text: They start sharing thoughts about a different topic

multiple-choice.question: What is the final point made in the transcript about maintaining a healthy brain in the face of thought germs and their spread?

options.label: A
options.text: Be cautious of thoughts that have passed through a lot of other brains and may be highly infectious

options.label: B
options.text: Ignore thoughts that poke you where you are weakest and most vulnerable

options.label: C

options.label: D

title: Could You Survive 2.5 Million Years Ago?

options.text: Starvation due to lack of food

options.label: C
options.text: Diseases such as tapeworms, tuberculosis, and malaria

options.label: D
options.text: Injuries from encounters with wild animals

options.text: The availability of food and water

options.label: B
options.text: The presence of other human ancestors

options.label: C
options.text: The significantly colder global average temperatures

options.text: To simplify mathematical calculations and conversions

options.label: A
options.text: It allowed them to maintain their power through other means

options.label: B
options.text: It had no effect on their power and social status

options.label: C
options.text: It decreased their power by reducing their ability to manipulate local units

options.label: D
options.text: It increased their power by allowing them to control the new system

multiple-choice.question: What were some of the key benefits of the metric system for the Revolutionaries?

options.label: A
options.text: It allowed them to collect taxes more efficiently and reduce church power

options.label: B
options.text: It prevented nobles from manipulating local units and promoted social equality

options.label: C
options.text: It facilitated international trade and economic growth

multiple-choice.question: What was the lasting impact of the French Revolution's adoption of the metric system?

options.label: A
options.text: It was abandoned after Napoleon's fall and had no lasting impact

options.label: B
options.text: It remained standard for formal use in France but had limited international impact

options.label: C
options.text: It was adopted by other European countries and spread globally, with some exceptions

options.label: D
options.text: It had a minor impact on science and medicine

multiple-choice.question: Why did the British Empire initially resist the adoption of the metric system?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it was a symbol of global conformity and threatened traditional units

options.label: B
options.text: Because it was associated with revolutionary ideas and the French Revolution

options.label: C
options.text: Because it was a departure from traditional units and required significant changes

options.label: D
options.text: Because it was seen as a threat to British economic and scientific dominance

multiple-choice.question: Why is the metric system widely used in science and medicine?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it is a symbol of global conformity and international cooperation

options.label: B
options.text: Because it is a traditional system and has been in use for centuries

options.label: C
options.text: Because it is based on universal constants and provides consistent measurements

options.label: D
options.text: Because it is a flexible system that can be adapted to different contexts

multiple-choice.question: How have standards based on physical prototypes been replaced in the metric system?

options.label: A
options.text: They have been replaced with standards based on arbitrary authority and local traditions

options.label: B
options.text: They have been replaced with standards based on mathematical and natural relationships

options.label: C
options.text: They have been replaced with standards based on universal constants and precision technology

options.label: D
options.text: They have been replaced with standards based on traditional units and social norms

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the metric system's adoption by the French Revolution?

options.label: A
options.text: It was a minor accomplishment with limited impact on science and medicine

options.label: B
options.text: It was a symbol of revolutionary ideas and had limited practical impact

options.label: C
options.text: It was a major accomplishment for humanity, enabling consistent measurements and scientific progress

options.label: D
